20110120010007.000|20110120010009.000|TR0|KATHLEEN PARKER, CO-HOST:  Good evening.  
20110120010009.000|20110120010011.000|TR0|I'm Kathleen Parker.
20110120010011.000|20110120010013.000|TR0|
20110120010013.000|20110120010015.000|TR0|ELIOT SPITZER, CO-HOST:  And I'm Eliot 
20110120010015.000|20110120010017.000|TR0|Spitzer.  Welcome to the program.  We will 
20110120010017.000|20110120010020.000|TR0|get to President Obama's historic summit 
20110120010020.000|20110120010022.000|TR0|with his Chinese counterpart in a moment.  
20110120010022.000|20110120010024.000|TR0|But first breaking news.  A federal grand 
20110120010024.000|20110120010026.000|TR0|jury has just returned an indictment 
20110120010026.000|20110120010028.000|TR0|against the Arizona shooter, Jared 
20110120010028.000|20110120010030.000|TR0|Loughner.  It charges Loughner with 
20110120010030.000|20110120010033.000|TR0|attempting to kill Congresswoman Gabrielle 
20110120010033.000|20110120010035.000|TR0|Giffords and her two aides, Ron Barber and 
20110120010035.000|20110120010037.000|TR0|Pamela Simon.  Prosecutors indicated these 
20110120010037.000|20110120010039.000|TR0|are potentially death penalty charges.  
20110120010039.000|20110120010041.000|TR0|U.S. attorney Dennis Burke said, and I 
20110120010041.000|20110120010043.000|TR0|quote, "Today's charges are just the 
20110120010043.000|20110120010046.000|TR0|beginning."
20110120010046.000|20110120010048.000|TR0|
20110120010048.000|20110120010050.000|TR0|PARKER:  This news comes on the same day 
20110120010050.000|20110120010052.000|TR0|that we learned that Giffords now has the 
20110120010052.000|20110120010054.000|TR0|strength to stand on her own.  What's 
20110120010054.000|20110120010057.000|TR0|more, her doctors said she was actually 
20110120010057.000|20110120010059.000|TR0|able with a bit of help to walk to the 
20110120010059.000|20110120010101.000|TR0|window in her hospital room and look out 
20110120010101.000|20110120010103.000|TR0|at a view of the mountains around Tucson.
20110120010103.000|20110120010105.000|TR0|
20110120010105.000|20110120010107.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Let's bring in our senior legal 
20110120010107.000|20110120010110.000|TR0|analyst, Jeff Toobin. Jeff, thanks for 
20110120010110.000|20110120010112.000|TR0|joining us.
20110120010112.000|20110120010114.000|TR0|
20110120010114.000|20110120010116.000|TR0|JEFFREY TOOBIN, CNN SENIOR LEGAL ANALYST 
20110120010116.000|20110120010118.000|TR0|(via telephone):  Hi, Eliot.
20110120010118.000|20110120010120.000|TR0|
20110120010120.000|20110120010123.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Jeff, first question is, why are 
20110120010123.000|20110120010125.000|TR0|these just the attempted murder cases?  
20110120010125.000|20110120010127.000|TR0|What's happening to the murder charges? 
20110120010127.000|20110120010129.000|TR0|There were people killed in this 
20110120010129.000|20110120010131.000|TR0|outrageous shooting.  And why not death 
20110120010131.000|20110120010134.000|TR0|penalty charges yet?
20110120010134.000|20110120010136.000|TR0|
20110120010136.000|20110120010138.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  Well, this is really the 
20110120010138.000|20110120010140.000|TR0|beginning of a long legal process.  Under 
20110120010140.000|20110120010142.000|TR0|federal law, the grand jury has to issue 
20110120010142.000|20110120010144.000|TR0|some indictment within 30 days after his 
20110120010144.000|20110120010147.000|TR0|arrest.  This has been a little more than 
20110120010147.000|20110120010149.000|TR0|a week.  So the initial charges are, 
20110120010149.000|20110120010151.000|TR0|frankly, the simplest ones to bring.
20110120010151.000|20110120010153.000|TR0|
20110120010153.000|20110120010155.000|TR0|The death penalty case under federal law 
20110120010155.000|20110120010157.000|TR0|is going to be somewhat complicated 
20110120010157.000|20110120010200.000|TR0|because the murders, for example, of the 
20110120010200.000|20110120010202.000|TR0|non-federal employees, little Christina 
20110120010202.000|20110120010204.000|TR0|Green and the retirees -- those are not 
20110120010204.000|20110120010206.000|TR0|federal crimes.  Those are going to have 
20110120010206.000|20110120010208.000|TR0|to be prosecuted under Arizona state law.
20110120010208.000|20110120010211.000|TR0|
20110120010211.000|20110120010213.000|TR0|The case about murdering the judge is 
20110120010213.000|20110120010215.000|TR0|somewhat more complicated legally because 
20110120010215.000|20110120010217.000|TR0|the government will have to establish that 
20110120010217.000|20110120010219.000|TR0|his activity by the shopping center was 
20110120010219.000|20110120010221.000|TR0|part of his work as a judge.  Now, there 
20110120010221.000|20110120010224.000|TR0|is the possibility that that's true 
20110120010224.000|20110120010226.000|TR0|because he was apparently going to see 
20110120010226.000|20110120010228.000|TR0|Congresswoman Giffords, but that's going 
20110120010228.000|20110120010230.000|TR0|to take more information, more 
20110120010230.000|20110120010232.000|TR0|investigation.
20110120010232.000|20110120010234.000|TR0|
20110120010234.000|20110120010237.000|TR0|This is really what you think of as a 
20110120010237.000|20110120010239.000|TR0|placeholder indictment. There's a long way 
20110120010239.000|20110120010241.000|TR0|for the grand jury to investigate before 
20110120010241.000|20110120010243.000|TR0|there's a trial, and it's certainly 
20110120010243.000|20110120010245.000|TR0|possible they will add death penalty 
20110120010245.000|20110120010248.000|TR0|(INAUDIBLE)
20110120010248.000|20110120010250.000|TR0|
20110120010250.000|20110120010252.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Jeff, let me ask you to explain 
20110120010252.000|20110120010254.000|TR0|something you just said that maybe only 
20110120010254.000|20110120010256.000|TR0|lawyers would understand.  Why does the 
20110120010256.000|20110120010258.000|TR0|charge against (SIC) the judge have to be 
20110120010258.000|20110120010301.000|TR0|related to his official work in order for 
20110120010301.000|20110120010303.000|TR0|it to be a death penalty case?
20110120010303.000|20110120010305.000|TR0|
20110120010305.000|20110120010307.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  Because federal law only covers 
20110120010307.000|20110120010309.000|TR0|murder of federal employees in the course 
20110120010309.000|20110120010311.000|TR0|of their duties.  Now, fortunately, 
20110120010311.000|20110120010314.000|TR0|Congresswoman Giffords survived, so it's 
20110120010314.000|20110120010316.000|TR0|not a murder count, it's an attempted 
20110120010316.000|20110120010318.000|TR0|murder count.  But federal law applies to 
20110120010318.000|20110120010320.000|TR0|federal employees who are working, not 
20110120010320.000|20110120010322.000|TR0|just federal employees who happen to be 
20110120010322.000|20110120010325.000|TR0|walking down the street.  And the factual 
20110120010325.000|20110120010327.000|TR0|issue that needs to be investigated is, 
20110120010327.000|20110120010329.000|TR0|was Judge Roll's visit to Congresswoman 
20110120010329.000|20110120010331.000|TR0|Giffords just a casual encounter by 
20110120010331.000|20110120010333.000|TR0|accident, or was it part of his duties, 
20110120010333.000|20110120010335.000|TR0|trying to get support for the court?  That 
20110120010335.000|20110120010338.000|TR0|is a factual issue that will take some 
20110120010338.000|20110120010340.000|TR0|investigation.
20110120010340.000|20110120010342.000|TR0|
20110120010342.000|20110120010344.000|TR0|There's no impediment to the federal 
20110120010344.000|20110120010346.000|TR0|government going back to the grand jury 
20110120010346.000|20110120010348.000|TR0|and adding those counts later.  But I 
20110120010348.000|20110120010351.000|TR0|think at this initial stage, they wanted 
20110120010351.000|20110120010353.000|TR0|to get the simple counts, which were 
20110120010353.000|20110120010355.000|TR0|attempting to murder the congresswoman, 
20110120010355.000|20110120010357.000|TR0|which, given the evidence that's come out 
20110120010357.000|20110120010359.000|TR0|already, seems like a very straightforward 
20110120010359.000|20110120010402.000|TR0|case legally.
20110120010402.000|20110120010404.000|TR0|
20110120010404.000|20110120010406.000|TR0|PARKER:  Well, Jeff, that all sounds very 
20110120010406.000|20110120010408.000|TR0|complicated to me.  But given what we know 
20110120010408.000|20110120010410.000|TR0|about the case, do you expect there will 
20110120010410.000|20110120010412.000|TR0|be death penalty charges against him on 
20110120010412.000|20110120010415.000|TR0|some of these other cases eventually?
20110120010415.000|20110120010417.000|TR0|
20110120010417.000|20110120010419.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  Absolutely.  In fact, the 
20110120010419.000|20110120010421.000|TR0|accompanying statement by the U.S. 
20110120010421.000|20110120010423.000|TR0|attorney, said that the death penalty 
20110120010423.000|20110120010425.000|TR0|review process, which is what any death 
20110120010425.000|20110120010428.000|TR0|penalty case has to go through in the 
20110120010428.000|20110120010430.000|TR0|federal government -- the Justice 
20110120010430.000|20110120010432.000|TR0|Department has to prove the seeking of the 
20110120010432.000|20110120010434.000|TR0|death penalty.  That is now beginning.  
20110120010434.000|20110120010436.000|TR0|And also, the state of Arizona, which has 
20110120010436.000|20110120010439.000|TR0|the death penalty, very well could seek 
20110120010439.000|20110120010441.000|TR0|the death penalty in an entirely separate 
20110120010441.000|20110120010443.000|TR0|case covering the murders of the 
20110120010443.000|20110120010445.000|TR0|individuals who were not federal 
20110120010445.000|20110120010447.000|TR0|employees, including, of course, the 
20110120010447.000|20110120010449.000|TR0|little 9-year-old girl.
20110120010449.000|20110120010452.000|TR0|
20110120010452.000|20110120010454.000|TR0|PARKER:  Right.
20110120010454.000|20110120010456.000|TR0|
20110120010456.000|20110120010458.000|TR0|SPITZER:  And Jeff, something that is just 
20110120010458.000|20110120010500.000|TR0|basic for you because you were a federal 
20110120010500.000|20110120010502.000|TR0|prosecutor for many years -- the fact that 
20110120010502.000|20110120010505.000|TR0|this is an indictment doesn't mean that 
20110120010505.000|20110120010507.000|TR0|there won't be subsequent indictments. 
20110120010507.000|20110120010509.000|TR0|Indictments can be amended, added to, 
20110120010509.000|20110120010511.000|TR0|other charges.  Explain how that works and 
20110120010511.000|20110120010513.000|TR0|what the likely timeframe would be, based 
20110120010513.000|20110120010516.000|TR0|on your experience as a prosecutor.
20110120010516.000|20110120010518.000|TR0|
20110120010518.000|20110120010520.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  Well, as I said, the initial 
20110120010520.000|20110120010522.000|TR0|indictment had to be within 30 days, and 
20110120010522.000|20110120010524.000|TR0|they are well within 30 days.  This could 
20110120010524.000|20110120010526.000|TR0|certainly go on for many more months.  
20110120010526.000|20110120010529.000|TR0|There is no rush.  Jared Loughner is 
20110120010529.000|20110120010531.000|TR0|certainly not going anywhere.  He's not 
20110120010531.000|20110120010533.000|TR0|getting out on bail.  He's not a threat to 
20110120010533.000|20110120010535.000|TR0|anyone where he is.  And it's very 
20110120010535.000|20110120010537.000|TR0|important for the government to do a 
20110120010537.000|20110120010539.000|TR0|thorough investigation.  It could easily 
20110120010539.000|20110120010542.000|TR0|take several months.
20110120010542.000|20110120010544.000|TR0|
20110120010544.000|20110120010546.000|TR0|And in the course -- if they issue further 
20110120010546.000|20110120010548.000|TR0|indictments, those are known as 
20110120010548.000|20110120010550.000|TR0|superseding indictments, and it could be 
20110120010550.000|20110120010553.000|TR0|more than one superseding indictment.  
20110120010553.000|20110120010555.000|TR0|That is common in complicated cases.
20110120010555.000|20110120010557.000|TR0|
20110120010557.000|20110120010559.000|TR0|But I don't think the federal government 
20110120010559.000|20110120010601.000|TR0|is going to be in any rush to get him on 
20110120010601.000|20110120010603.000|TR0|trial before they have investigated this 
20110120010603.000|20110120010606.000|TR0|case to a faretheewell because, obviously, 
20110120010606.000|20110120010608.000|TR0|it's extremely important.  And with the 
20110120010608.000|20110120010610.000|TR0|death penalty on the table, they're going 
20110120010610.000|20110120010612.000|TR0|to be subject to a great deal of scrutiny, 
20110120010612.000|20110120010614.000|TR0|a great deal of defense effort, and there 
20110120010614.000|20110120010616.000|TR0|really is no rush at this point because 
20110120010616.000|20110120010619.000|TR0|Loughner isn't going anywhere.
20110120010619.000|20110120010621.000|TR0|
20110120010621.000|20110120010623.000|TR0|PARKER:  Jeff, just on these three counts, 
20110120010623.000|20110120010625.000|TR0|what are the maximum penalties that he 
20110120010625.000|20110120010627.000|TR0|could face?
20110120010627.000|20110120010630.000|TR0|
20110120010630.000|20110120010632.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  It's 20 years, I believe -- I 
20110120010632.000|20110120010634.000|TR0|don't have it in front of me -- 20 years 
20110120010634.000|20110120010636.000|TR0|on each count.  But it could easily be a 
20110120010636.000|20110120010638.000|TR0|life sentence if they were lined up 
20110120010638.000|20110120010640.000|TR0|consecutively.
20110120010640.000|20110120010643.000|TR0|
20110120010643.000|20110120010645.000|TR0|PARKER:  I think right.  I think 20 years, 
20110120010645.000|20110120010647.000|TR0|what I saw in one of the documents.  And 
20110120010647.000|20110120010649.000|TR0|oddly, Jeff, I think I remember seeing 
20110120010649.000|20110120010651.000|TR0|shortly after the shooting, somewhere the 
20110120010651.000|20110120010653.000|TR0|assertion was made that the judge was 
20110120010653.000|20110120010656.000|TR0|going to meet the congresswoman in order 
20110120010656.000|20110120010658.000|TR0|to discuss with her how to get more 
20110120010658.000|20110120010700.000|TR0|resources to clear up the backlog in the 
20110120010700.000|20110120010702.000|TR0|federal court system, which I presume -- 
20110120010702.000|20110120010704.000|TR0|and tell me if I'm right about this -- 
20110120010704.000|20110120010707.000|TR0|would then be a sufficient basis to make 
20110120010707.000|20110120010709.000|TR0|-- put him within the ambit of his work, 
20110120010709.000|20110120010711.000|TR0|make this a federal death penalty case.  
20110120010711.000|20110120010713.000|TR0|Am I correct about that?
20110120010713.000|20110120010715.000|TR0|
20110120010715.000|20110120010717.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  That's -- that would be the 
20110120010717.000|20110120010720.000|TR0|government's theory.  And it's an unusual 
20110120010720.000|20110120010722.000|TR0|setting.  Obviously, it is -- the statute 
20110120010722.000|20110120010724.000|TR0|is usually meant to -- more directly about 
20110120010724.000|20110120010726.000|TR0|someone, a federal government employee, 
20110120010726.000|20110120010728.000|TR0|doing his job.  For example, a judge on 
20110120010728.000|20110120010730.000|TR0|the bench.  But a judge who is seeking to 
20110120010730.000|20110120010733.000|TR0|get more resources for the court could be 
20110120010733.000|20110120010735.000|TR0|seen as someone doing his job.  But it's 
20110120010735.000|20110120010737.000|TR0|no surprise that they didn't put that 
20110120010737.000|20110120010739.000|TR0|charge in yet because it is more factually 
20110120010739.000|20110120010741.000|TR0|legally complicated. It needs more 
20110120010741.000|20110120010743.000|TR0|investigation.  And there's no reason to 
20110120010743.000|20110120010746.000|TR0|put a charge in now when it could easily 
20110120010746.000|20110120010748.000|TR0|be added down the road when the 
20110120010748.000|20110120010750.000|TR0|investigation is complete.
20110120010750.000|20110120010752.000|TR0|
20110120010752.000|20110120010754.000|TR0|SPITZER:  And as you and I both know, 
20110120010754.000|20110120010757.000|TR0|having been -- you a federal prosecutor, I 
20110120010757.000|20110120010759.000|TR0|a state prosecutor -- there's always this 
20110120010759.000|20110120010801.000|TR0|dance that goes on between the two 
20110120010801.000|20110120010803.000|TR0|jurisdictions.  Do you think that because 
20110120010803.000|20110120010805.000|TR0|the federal government has now brought the 
20110120010805.000|20110120010807.000|TR0|first indictment, the state is likely to 
20110120010807.000|20110120010810.000|TR0|act more quickly to show that it's on the 
20110120010810.000|20110120010812.000|TR0|case, that it's doing things, it is 
20110120010812.000|20110120010814.000|TR0|pursuing justice as aggressively as the 
20110120010814.000|20110120010816.000|TR0|federal government?
20110120010816.000|20110120010818.000|TR0|
20110120010818.000|20110120010820.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  You know, I don't think 
20110120010820.000|20110120010823.000|TR0|necessarily that's the case.  I think 
20110120010823.000|20110120010825.000|TR0|there is going to be a lot of coordination 
20110120010825.000|20110120010827.000|TR0|between the Pima County district attorney 
20110120010827.000|20110120010829.000|TR0|and the local U.S. attorney.  There really 
20110120010829.000|20110120010831.000|TR0|is no reason for the jurisdictions to have 
20110120010831.000|20110120010834.000|TR0|any sort of race.  This case is too 
20110120010834.000|20110120010836.000|TR0|important.  The emotions are too raw.  I 
20110120010836.000|20110120010838.000|TR0|am sure there will be a coordination here. 
20110120010838.000|20110120010840.000|TR0|    The very important point is that Jared 
20110120010840.000|20110120010842.000|TR0|Loughner is in custody. He's not going 
20110120010842.000|20110120010844.000|TR0|anywhere.  There is plenty of time for 
20110120010844.000|20110120010847.000|TR0|both the jurisdictions to proceed.  And so 
20110120010847.000|20110120010849.000|TR0|far, there's been good coordination, and I 
20110120010849.000|20110120010851.000|TR0|see no reason to believe that will end.
20110120010851.000|20110120010853.000|TR0|
20110120010853.000|20110120010855.000|TR0|SPITZER:  I want to cycle back to 
20110120010855.000|20110120010857.000|TR0|something you said a few moments ago, 
20110120010857.000|20110120010900.000|TR0|which is there's a very careful process at 
20110120010900.000|20110120010902.000|TR0|main Justice -- how people refer to the 
20110120010902.000|20110120010904.000|TR0|Justice Department in Washington -- before 
20110120010904.000|20110120010906.000|TR0|any of the U.S. attorneys' offices can 
20110120010906.000|20110120010908.000|TR0|bring a death penalty case. Explain why 
20110120010908.000|20110120010911.000|TR0|that is and how that process actually is 
20110120010911.000|20110120010913.000|TR0|likely to go.
20110120010913.000|20110120010915.000|TR0|
20110120010915.000|20110120010917.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  There are lots of federal crimes 
20110120010917.000|20110120010919.000|TR0|that are technically eligible for the 
20110120010919.000|20110120010921.000|TR0|death penalty, but the Justice Department 
20110120010921.000|20110120010924.000|TR0|very rarely seeks the death penalty 
20110120010924.000|20110120010926.000|TR0|because, of course, it is the ultimate 
20110120010926.000|20110120010928.000|TR0|sanction and it is not something any 
20110120010928.000|20110120010930.000|TR0|jurisdiction, particularly the U.S. 
20110120010930.000|20110120010932.000|TR0|government, does lightly.  One goal of the 
20110120010932.000|20110120010934.000|TR0|federal government is to have some 
20110120010934.000|20110120010937.000|TR0|consistency of application.
20110120010937.000|20110120010939.000|TR0|
20110120010939.000|20110120010941.000|TR0|The U.S. attorneys' offices operate very 
20110120010941.000|20110120010943.000|TR0|independently.  They make a lot of 
20110120010943.000|20110120010945.000|TR0|decisions on their own.  But the death 
20110120010945.000|20110120010948.000|TR0|penalty is so important that the attorney 
20110120010948.000|20110120010950.000|TR0|general, and the attorney general himself, 
20110120010950.000|20110120010952.000|TR0|gets involved in all death penalty 
20110120010952.000|20110120010954.000|TR0|decisions, makes sure that a crime that 
20110120010954.000|20110120010956.000|TR0|gets the death penalty in one jurisdiction 
20110120010956.000|20110120010958.000|TR0|also gets it in another, and doesn't get 
20110120010958.000|20110120011001.000|TR0|the death penalty in one jurisdiction also 
20110120011001.000|20110120011003.000|TR0|doesn't get it in another.  Consistency of 
20110120011003.000|20110120011005.000|TR0|application is the goal, and that's why 
20110120011005.000|20110120011007.000|TR0|it's -- that decision is centralized at 
20110120011007.000|20110120011009.000|TR0|the Justice Department.  The U.S. attorney 
20110120011009.000|20110120011011.000|TR0|on his own or her own can't seek the death 
20110120011011.000|20110120011014.000|TR0|penalty without the OK of the attorney 
20110120011014.000|20110120011016.000|TR0|general.
20110120011016.000|20110120011018.000|TR0|
20110120011018.000|20110120011020.000|TR0|SPITZER:  And not only is it the right 
20110120011020.000|20110120011022.000|TR0|thing to do, of course, to make sure that 
20110120011022.000|20110120011025.000|TR0|there's consistency across all of the 
20110120011025.000|20110120011027.000|TR0|districts, but we all know that every 
20110120011027.000|20110120011029.000|TR0|decision -- that every case that produces 
20110120011029.000|20110120011031.000|TR0|a death penalty verdict by the jury is 
20110120011031.000|20110120011033.000|TR0|going to be appealed all the way up, and 
20110120011033.000|20110120011035.000|TR0|every decision that has been made by the 
20110120011035.000|20110120011038.000|TR0|Justice Department will be scrutinized.  
20110120011038.000|20110120011040.000|TR0|And so they're very meticulous in how they 
20110120011040.000|20110120011042.000|TR0|do this to make sure that it will 
20110120011042.000|20110120011044.000|TR0|withstand that appeal.
20110120011044.000|20110120011046.000|TR0|
20110120011046.000|20110120011048.000|TR0|TOOBIN:  That's right.  Death penalty 
20110120011048.000|20110120011051.000|TR0|cases get a completely different level of 
20110120011051.000|20110120011053.000|TR0|scrutiny by appeals courts than any other 
20110120011053.000|20110120011055.000|TR0|kind of cases.  They are much more heavily 
20110120011055.000|20110120011057.000|TR0|reviewed.  They take much longer to get 
20110120011057.000|20110120011059.000|TR0|through the legal process.  That's why we 
20110120011059.000|20110120011102.000|TR0|so often hear about people who've been on 
20110120011102.000|20110120011104.000|TR0|death row for 10 and even 20 years.

20110120014037.000|20110120014039.000|TR0|I think in a case like this, we obviously 
20110120014039.000|20110120014042.000|TR0|know that he committed the offense.  
20110120014042.000|20110120014044.000|TR0|Usually that's a big battle in a death 
20110120014044.000|20110120014046.000|TR0|case, to try to show that the person is 
20110120014046.000|20110120014048.000|TR0|innocent.  Factually, there's no question 
20110120014048.000|20110120014050.000|TR0|that he did it.  So the focus here is 
20110120014050.000|20110120014053.000|TR0|going to be in the sentencing phase to say 
20110120014053.000|20110120014055.000|TR0|that mental illness caused and contributed 
20110120014055.000|20110120014057.000|TR0|to this crime and that death is not an 
20110120014057.000|20110120014059.000|TR0|appropriate penalty.
20110120014059.000|20110120014101.000|TR0|
20110120014101.000|20110120014103.000|TR0|PARKER:  But how do you even make a case 
20110120014103.000|20110120014106.000|TR0|for mental illness of this case?  I mean, 
20110120014106.000|20110120014108.000|TR0|originally he looked so wild you'd think 
20110120014108.000|20110120014110.000|TR0|well, of course, he's mentally ill and he 
20110120014110.000|20110120014112.000|TR0|does seem to show symptoms of various 
20110120014112.000|20110120014114.000|TR0|afflictions.  But, he did leave a very 
20110120014114.000|20110120014116.000|TR0|distinct trail.  He left notes where he 
20110120014116.000|20110120014119.000|TR0|have his intent.  He even put in earplugs 
20110120014119.000|20110120014121.000|TR0|to protect his own ears from the sound of 
20110120014121.000|20110120014123.000|TR0|the shots.  So where do you go with that?
20110120014123.000|20110120014125.000|TR0|
20110120014125.000|20110120014127.000|TR0|CALLAN:  Well, it's very, very hard for 
20110120014127.000|20110120014130.000|TR0|the defense to go any place with that 
20110120014130.000|20110120014132.000|TR0|because yes, he did plan and he clearly 
20110120014132.000|20110120014134.000|TR0|knew what he was doing.  And I think 
20110120014134.000|20110120014136.000|TR0|that's why he doesn't have a good insanity 
20110120014136.000|20110120014138.000|TR0|defense.  But on the other hand, juries 
20110120014138.000|20110120014140.000|TR0|are very hesitant to put people to death 
20110120014140.000|20110120014143.000|TR0|when they think that mental illness caused 
20110120014143.000|20110120014145.000|TR0|or contributed to part of the crime.  I 
20110120014145.000|20110120014147.000|TR0|don't think anybody can look at this guy 
20110120014147.000|20110120014149.000|TR0|and say he's not mentally ill.  And as a 
20110120014149.000|20110120014151.000|TR0|matter of fact, many, many serious 
20110120014151.000|20110120014153.000|TR0|criminals are mentally ill.  But he goes 
20110120014153.000|20110120014156.000|TR0|beyond the pale.  I mean, he's clearly 
20110120014156.000|20110120014158.000|TR0|someone who's disturbed.  Do you want to 
20110120014158.000|20110120014200.000|TR0|put that kind of a person to death?
20110120014200.000|20110120014202.000|TR0|
20110120014202.000|20110120014204.000|TR0|SPITZER:  You know, Paul, in so many of

20110120014450.000|20110120014452.000|TR0|PARKER:  When you say unintentional

20110120014454.000|20110120014456.000|TR0|by letter of the law because he didn't

20110120014458.000|20110120014501.000|TR0|that the fellow died as a result of his 
20110120014501.000|20110120014503.000|TR0|shooting wildly into the crowd?
20110120014503.000|20110120014505.000|TR0|
20110120014505.000|20110120014507.000|TR0|CALLAN:  There are two kinds of killings.  
20110120014507.000|20110120014509.000|TR0|We talk about, for instance, the first 
20110120014509.000|20110120014511.000|TR0|degree murder usually is when you actually 
20110120014511.000|20110120014514.000|TR0|point the weapon intending to kill a 
20110120014514.000|20110120014516.000|TR0|specific victim.  There is a second kind 
20110120014516.000|20110120014518.000|TR0|of killing that the law, by the way, views 
20110120014518.000|20110120014520.000|TR0|as virtually the same called the reckless 
20110120014520.000|20110120014522.000|TR0|killing.  And if you fire that shot into a 
20110120014522.000|20110120014525.000|TR0|crowd, any reasonable person would know 
20110120014525.000|20110120014527.000|TR0|that someone might die so the law will 
20110120014527.000|20110120014529.000|TR0|hold you just as culpable.  But I think 
20110120014529.000|20110120014531.000|TR0|people and ordinary jurors look at it 
20110120014531.000|20110120014533.000|TR0|differently.  They're going to say well, 
20110120014533.000|20110120014535.000|TR0|he was out to assassinate the 
20110120014535.000|20110120014538.000|TR0|congresswoman.  And I'm not saying that 
20110120014538.000|20110120014540.000|TR0|anybody is going to buy these arguments, 
20110120014540.000|20110120014542.000|TR0|but I'm saying these are the only 
20110120014542.000|20110120014544.000|TR0|arguments that defense attorneys have.  
20110120014544.000|20110120014546.000|TR0|They're going to say he set out to kill 
20110120014546.000|20110120014548.000|TR0|the congresswoman.  The other killings 
20110120014548.000|20110120014551.000|TR0|were accidental killings.  He doesn't 
20110120014551.000|20110120014553.000|TR0|deserve death for that.  That's the 
20110120014553.000|20110120014555.000|TR0|argument they make.
20110120014555.000|20110120014557.000|TR0|
20110120014557.000|20110120014559.000|TR0|SPITZER:  Not surprising.  The prosecutor 
20110120014559.000|20110120014602.000|TR0|he's coming at, I don't think you're going

20110120014610.000|20110120014612.000|TR0|miles an hour down a road and somebody is

20110120015003.000|20110120015005.000|TR0|PARKER:  Jeff, we keep hearing this 
20110120015005.000|20110120015007.000|TR0|forecast that the Chinese economy is going 
20110120015007.000|20110120015010.000|TR0|to overtake ours in 10 to 20 years.  Is 
20110120015010.000|20110120015012.000|TR0|that inevitable?  Is there anything we can 
20110120015012.000|20110120015014.000|TR0|do to turn that around?
20110120015014.000|20110120015016.000|TR0|
20110120015016.000|20110120015018.000|TR0|SACHS:  I think it's going to happen.  It 
20110120015018.000|20110120015021.000|TR0|doesn't mean that an average Chinese 
20110120015021.000|20110120015023.000|TR0|person is going to have the living 
20110120015023.000|20110120015025.000|TR0|standards of an average American because 
20110120015025.000|20110120015027.000|TR0|China has more than four times America's 
20110120015027.000|20110120015029.000|TR0|population so when economies reach the 
20110120015029.000|20110120015031.000|TR0|same level, it means that the average 
20110120015031.000|20110120015034.000|TR0|Chinese person will have one fourth of the 
20110120015034.000|20110120015036.000|TR0|income than an average American.  So China 
20110120015036.000|20110120015038.000|TR0|is not catching up in living standards but 
20110120015038.000|20110120015040.000|TR0|an absolutely size of the economy is very 
20110120015040.000|20110120015042.000|TR0|likely to overtake the United States in 
20110120015042.000|20110120015044.000|TR0|the next two decades.
20110120015044.000|20110120015047.000|TR0|
